verse.name: v1
verse.lines: In scarlet town where I was born, There was a fair maid dwellin'; Made ev'ry youth cry, Well-a-day! And her name was Barb'ra Ellen,

verse.name: v2
verse.lines: Twas in the merry month of May, When green buds they were swellin'. Sweet William on this deathbed lay For the love of Barb'ra Ellen

verse.name: v3
verse.lines: He sent a servant to the town, To the place where she was dwellin'. "My master's sick and he bids you come If your name be Barb'ra Ellen.

verse.name: v4
verse.lines: Then slowly, slowly she got up, And slowly she went nigh him; And as she drew the curtain back: "Young man, I think you're dyin!"

verse.name: v5
verse.lines: "O, ken you not in yonder town, In the place where we were dwellin', You gave a health to the ladies all, But you slighted Barb'ra Ellen."

verse.name: v6
verse.lines: "O, yes I ken. I ken it well. In the place where we were dwellin', I gave a health to the ladies all, But my love to Barb'ra Ellen."

verse.name: v7
verse.lines: Then slowly went she down the stairs. He trembled like an aspen. "Be kind, good friends and neighbors all, Be kind to Barb'ra Ellen."

verse.name: v8
verse.lines: And as she cross'd the wooded fields, She heard his deathbell knellin', And ev'ry stroke, it spoke her name "Hard-hearted Barb'ra Ellen."

verse.name: v9
verse.lines: She look'd to the east, she looked to the west. She saw his corpse a comin'. "O bearers, bearers, lay him down, For I think I too am dying'."

verse.name: v10
verse.lines: "O, Mother, Mother, make my bed, And make it long and narrow. Sweet William died for the love of me; I'll die for him of sorrow!"

verse.name: v11
verse.lines: "O, Father, Father, dig my grave, And dig it deep and narrow. Sweet William died for me today. I'll die for him tomorrow."

verse.name: v12
verse.lines: They buried her in the old churchyard. They buried him beside her, And from his heart grew a red, red rose, And from her heart a briar.

verse.name: v13
verse.lines: They climb'd right up the old church wall Till they couldn't climb no higher. They tied themselves in a true lover's' knot, The red rose around the briar.
